utterances: From the studios of NPR West, this is DAY TO DAY.
I'm Madeleine Brand.
And I'm James Hattori, sitting in for Alex Chadwick.
We start today's program with politics, the power of Oprah on the Democratic side and the Huckabee surge among Republicans.
Oprah Winfrey spent the weekend stumping with Barack Obama in three of the states with the earliest presidential contests.
In each of those states - Iowa, New Hampshire and South Carolina - polls show Senator Obama closing the gap with frontrunner Hillary Clinton, and in the case of Iowa he's now ahead.
Those polls were conducted before Oprah campaigned with him.
The double bill of Oprah and Obama drew more than 50,000 people to four events over the weekend.
NPR's Robert Smith went to the last show in Manchester, New Hampshire to see if anyone was swayed by the spectacle.
The Obama campaign may have been organizing the event but they weren't the only ones taking advantage of it.
The thousands of people lined up in the New Hampshire snow to catch a glimpse of Oprah were like political sitting ducks.
The Chris Dodd campaign worked the line.
Experience counts, support Chris Dodd.
The Oprah fans were also pestered by health care unions, anti-global warming groups, the AARP, and Dennis Kucinich fans like David Minow(ph).
Because there's lots of people here that are undecided and that don't know what Dennis stands for.
If Obama's got Oprah, what does Dennis Kucinich have?
Oh yeah, Sean Penn.
Yeah.
No offense, Mr. Penn, but it's hard to believe that you could pack a hockey arena like Oprah did.
Even if the voters of New Hampshire, like Sheila Berganone(ph), wouldn't admit that they could be swayed by celebrities.
I like Oprah, but no, I'll make my own mind.
Well, I mean, has she ever sold you a book?
Every book, actually.
Have you ever bought something that was featured on her show?
I have.
So what's the difference?
A candidate, a book, a magazine?
So it's a national decision for a president compared to reading a book.
That's a big difference.
Sure.
But it wasn't Obama's policy positions alone that got gray-haired women in brightly colored sweaters doing the wave.
(Soundbite of cheering)
Jason Chamberline(ph) usually attends hockey games here and said it's a whole different vibes.
I guess the crowd just seems to be a little more yuppie than normal.
My dad asked me to go get him a beer and I just told him they weren't serving them.
I didn't even check.
But I don't think they are.
I didn't see any.
This crowd didn't need alcohol to go nuts.
Just the sight of Oprah's hand parting the curtains was enough.
SMITH: It turns out the Oprah's feel-good, self-help patter fits right in on a political stage.
If you keep doing the same thing, the same way all the time, you will get the same results.
So now is a time for change we can believe in.
(Soundbite of cheering)
She was so smooth and disarming, it took me a couple of beats to realize that the same thing she was referring to was Senator Hillary Clinton.
Oprah then took on the skeptics, who said she was just pedaling a candidate like so much merchandise on her show.
I know we all know the difference between book clubs and favorite things and free refrigerators.
I know you all were hoping I brought that refrigerator tonight.
(Soundbite of cheering)
I just couldn't swing it.
But even Senator Obama himself wasn't buying all that modesty.
He told a story about being backstage at Oprah's show with his press secretary.
(Soundbite of an airplane passing overhead)
But her death has become a political flashpoint.

We've seen the president mention it at a rally in West Virginia just this week, and in a video yesterday filmed outside the White House, released on social media, trying to tie what happened to lax immigration laws.
He said that Americans need to vote in more Republicans this fall to tighten those laws because of situations like this.
You know, there's a clear political strategy here, David.
You know, just look at what former House speaker Newt Gingrich, for example, said yesterday.
He said that if Mollie Tibbetts is a household name by October, Democrats will be in deep trouble.

Well, Democrats, of course, are pushing a different message right now - talking about Manafort, talking about Cohen, talking about corruption and wrongdoing - what they say is corruption and wrongdoing among Republicans.
Is that a message that will work for Democrats?
So Democrats are trying to paint this picture of Republicans as stuck in corruption and ethics scandals.
It's something that worked for them in 2006 when it helped them take back the House.

We saw more voters in 2006 say that that was very important to their vote - corruption and ethics scandals - as opposed to even the Iraq War - higher than that because of the Page Scandal that took place back then.
Of course, you know, Democrats have their own issues.
We've seen Bob Menendez, for example, in New Jersey face tougher-than-expected re-election after facing charges of corruption that ended in a mistrial.

And, you know, Democrats are hoping, though, calling attention to, you know, not just Manafort and Cohen and some of these other pieces of the Russia puzzle, but also some things, you know, more related to, you know, a whole host of other - you know, indicted Republicans, for example.
That - like, we've seen two this month.
And what about the I-word, impeachment?
I mean, we were talking to Richard Blumenthal - Blumenthal, the Democratic senator from Connecticut - yesterday.
I brought it up.
He seemed to not want to talk about it at all.
Right.
I mean, is that going to be part of the Democratic message maybe?
Most Democrats in Washington are trying to say that they need the Mueller investigation to play out.
And on the campaign trail, they're talking far more about health care costs and wage disparities.
But it might be hard to kind of hold off the Democratic base on this as more of this kind of information from the investigations comes out.
OK.
Domenico Montanaro is NPR's lead political editor.
Domenico, thanks.
You're welcome.

I think it's safe to say time is running out on Britain's plans for an orderly Brexit.
Right.
And it looks like the chances that the U.K.
will crash out of the European Union without a trade deal are rising.
Today, the U.K.
government is going to start issuing guidance to businesses, citizens and public organizations about how to prepare for something that was once unthinkable.
NPR's Frank Langfitt is covering this from London and joins us now.
Hey, Frank.
Hi, Rachel.
I mean, I don't want to go too far back in time, but it is important to remember how all this came about, right?
Yeah, it is.
You know, if you remember after the Brexit vote in 2016, officials said, oh, it's going to be really easy to work out a new relationship with the EU.
Right.
That has turned out not to be true at all.
And the U.K.
government basically overestimated the power that it had to get its way.
Now we're about seven months out from leaving the EU, and the U.K.
does risk walking away from this giant market in the European Union without any arrangements, which could be a big shock to the economy here.
